newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: N.Korea says opposition member from South defects.
newsitem.headline: N.Korea says opposition member from South defects.

text.p: A prominent South Korean religious figure who is a member of the main opposition party has defected to North Korea, according to official North Korean media quoted on Saturday.

The Tokyo-based Radio Press news agency quoted the state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) as saying Oh Ik-jae, the leader until 1995 of the 130-year old Chondokyo religious group, arrived in Pyongyang on Friday but did not say when he had defected from the South.
The spokeswoman for the main opposition National Congress for New Politics party, Park Sun-suck, said the party has not been able to confirm the report.
She stressed that although Oh still holds party membership, he no longer had a formal position in the party. She said he was an advisor to the party until May.
The party, whose leader has been accused by South Korea's ruling New Korea Party as being sympathetic towards the North, issued a statement demanding an immediate investigation by the government.
"The party will also conduct an investigation, and if the report is true Oh will be expelled from the party," the statement said.
"It was extremely shocking to hear the report of Oh Ik-jae's defection to the North and, if the report is true, it is very unfortunate and shameful to the Korean people."
Radio Press quoted KCNA as saying that Oh gave a speech on his arrival at Pyongyang's train station slamming South Korean President Kim Young-sam and praising the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il.
"I have not shirked from doing my best towards the peaceful reunification of the motherland by opposing this fascist presidency which is against reunification," he was quoted by KCNA as saying.
"I wanted to defect many years ago, but until now I could not fulfill this desire," Oh added.
"It is the highest honour to come to this great society guided by Kim Jong-il...and I wish to uphold the principle of unification of the nation made clear by the great leader Kim Il-sung."
Oh, 68, has also served on the Advisory Council on Democratic and Peaceful Unification, a presidential advisory body. But an official at the advisory body said Oh's term as advisor ended in June.
South Korean nationals must have government permission to travel to communist North Korea. Travelling to Pyongyang without permission is forbidden.
A South Korean National Unification Ministry official said Oh had not sought permission to travel to the North.

The two Koreas are still technically at war. The U.S. has recently led fresh efforts to start formal talks on a permanent peace arrangement to replace the fraying armistice that ended the 1950-53 Korean conflict.
